line: _The student of our early literature and language is indebted to the

Poem Title: M.DCCC.XLV.
line: zeal of Sir Thomas Phillipps, for the discovery of the following

Poem Title: M.DCCC.XLV.
line: interesting Fragment, which appears to have formed part of a volume that

Poem Title: M.DCCC.XLV.
line: contained Ælfric's Grammar and Glossary, probably of the Twelfth

Poem Title: M.DCCC.XLV.
line: Century. The fragments were discovered among the archives of Worcester

Poem Title: M.DCCC.XLV.
line: Cathedral; and in 1836 Sir Thomas Phillipps printed the whole of them in

Poem Title: M.DCCC.XLV.
line: folio. I know not whether the form or the typographical arrangement has

Poem Title: M.DCCC.XLV.
line: been the cause of the neglect of this publication; but it has escaped

Poem Title: M.DCCC.XLV.
line: both Mr. Wright and Mr. Thorpe. The former, in his interesting edition

Poem Title: M.DCCC.XLV.
line: of "The Latin Poems of Walter de Mapes," where he has given the literary

Poem Title: M.DCCC.XLV.
line: history of this legend with extracts, has not even referred to our

Poem Title: M.DCCC.XLV.
line: fragment; nor has Mr. Thorpe adverted to it in his publication of the

Poem Title: M.DCCC.XLV.
line: "Codex Exoniensis," which contains an Anglo-Saxon poem of the same kind,

Poem Title: M.DCCC.XLV.
line: with which it is interesting to compare this later version of the

Poem Title: M.DCCC.XLV.
line: legend. There is a portion of another semi-Saxon poem, entitled "The

Poem Title: M.DCCC.XLV.
line: Grave," printed in Mr. Conybeare's "Illustrations," and by Mr. Thorpe in

Poem Title: M.DCCC.XLV.
line: his "Analecta Anglo-Saxonica," which appears to be by the same hand, or

Poem Title: M.DCCC.XLV.
line: at any rate of the same school and age. Indeed some of the lines and

Poem Title: M.DCCC.XLV.
line: thoughts are identical with passages of the following poem. Mr. Thorpe

Poem Title: M.DCCC.XLV.
line: has justly called "The Grave" a singularly impressive and almost

Poem Title: M.DCCC.XLV.
line: appalling fragment; expressions equally characteristic of that with

Poem Title: M.DCCC.XLV.
line: which the reader is here presented._

Poem Title: M.DCCC.XLV.
M.DCCC.XLV.
line: _This impressive character, coupled with the interest which the fragment

Poem Title: M.DCCC.XLV.
line: possesses, as a specimen of the moral poetry of our ancestors, and as

Poem Title: M.DCCC.XLV.
line: throwing light upon the transition of our language from Saxon to

Poem Title: M.DCCC.XLV.
line: English, has been the motive for producing it in a more legible form

Poem Title: M.DCCC.XLV.
line: than that in which it first appeared._

M.DCCC.XLV.
line: _In one of the smaller poems (No. V.), printed by Mr. Wright with the

Poem Title: M.DCCC.XLV.
line: Owl and the Nightingale, from the Cottonian MS. Calig. A. ix. "The sorie

Poem Title: M.DCCC.XLV.
line: sowle maketh hire mone," in language not dissimilar to that used in the

Poem Title: M.DCCC.XLV.
line: following fragment; and the dreary imagery of the house appointed for

Poem Title: M.DCCC.XLV.
line: all living, and the punishment which awaits a wicked life at its close,

Poem Title: M.DCCC.XLV.
line: are painted in an equally fearful manner._

Poem Title: M.DCCC.XLV.
M.DCCC.XLV.
line: _Mr. Thorpe points to an Anglo-Saxon prose Homily as the original of the

Poem Title: M.DCCC.XLV.
line: poem on the same theme in the Exeter MS., which is repeated, with some

Poem Title: M.DCCC.XLV.
line: variation, in the Vercelli Codex. In a rude and simple age this dramatic

Poem Title: M.DCCC.XLV.
line: way of awakening the sinner to a sense of his perilous state, was

Poem Title: M.DCCC.XLV.
line: perhaps the most effective that could have been chosen, and it was

Poem Title: M.DCCC.XLV.
line: naturally a favorite with the moral and religious teachers for some

Poem Title: M.DCCC.XLV.
line: centuries. M. Karajan, in a very pleasing little publication

Poem Title: M.DCCC.XLV.
line: (Frülingsgabe für freunde Alterer Literatur, Wien 1839) has printed the

Poem Title: M.DCCC.XLV.
line: "Visio Philiberti," a Latin poem in dialogue on this subject, with two

Poem Title: M.DCCC.XLV.
line: old German versions; and the notes contain some interesting information

Poem Title: M.DCCC.XLV.
line: relating to similar compositions; but Mr. Wright's volume, before

Poem Title: M.DCCC.XLV.
line: referred to, contains ample illustrations of the legend in all

Poem Title: M.DCCC.XLV.
line: languages._

Poem Title: M.DCCC.XLV.
M.DCCC.XLV.
line: _The fragment here given, it will be seen, is very defective. An attempt

Poem Title: M.DCCC.XLV.
line: has been made to supply words which were wanting, from the mutilation of

Poem Title: M.DCCC.XLV.
line: the MS. leaves; but what is engrafted on the original is scrupulously

Poem Title: M.DCCC.XLV.
line: distinguished by the Italic character. A version has also been added,

Poem Title: M.DCCC.XLV.
line: the imperfections of which those who are acquainted with the

Poem Title: M.DCCC.XLV.
line: difficulties of such renderings will best know how to excuse._

Poem Title: M.DCCC.XLV.
M.DCCC.XLV.
line: _The language of this poem seems to have a striking resemblance to that

Poem Title: M.DCCC.XLV.
line: of one of the MSS. of La[gh]amon, and we may hope, when the lovers of

Poem Title: M.DCCC.XLV.
line: our early lore shall be favoured with the long and anxiously expected

Poem Title: M.DCCC.XLV.
line: edition of that work by Sir Frederick Madden, that much light will be

Poem Title: M.DCCC.XLV.
line: thrown upon the history of the transitions of our language._

Poem Title: M.DCCC.XLV.
M.DCCC.XLV.
line: _For what has been already done by Conybeare, Price, Kemble, Thorpe,

Poem Title: M.DCCC.XLV.
line: Madden, Stevenson, Wright, Way and others, the present writer is most

Poem Title: M.DCCC.XLV.
line: grateful; but he would wish to see the same spirit and enthusiasm, the

Poem Title: M.DCCC.XLV.
line: same unwearied zeal displayed in the elucidation of the noble remains of

Poem Title: M.DCCC.XLV.
line: our Anglo-Saxon ancestors, and of the interesting stores of our early

Poem Title: M.DCCC.XLV.
line: literature and language, which has been so long a distinguishing feature

Poem Title: M.DCCC.XLV.
line: of Germany, whose example has of late years lighted up a similar

Poem Title: M.DCCC.XLV.
line: patriotic flame in France and Belgium._
